column5: We recently had a great week in Northwest Ont. Only complaint was we did not get into any larger walleyes. Lots of mid-size fish...just not the larger ones. Any tips on going for size versus numbers? Any advice appreciated. Thanks, Bill

We caught most if not all of our larger fish in deeper water. The larger fish came out of the 15-25' range, where most of the regulars came out of the 8-15' range. However, some waters that have a lot of the regular sized fish do not seem to have any (many) large fish. For example, some out lakes that are known for numbers don't seem to have the quality fish, but you might catch 100 in a day. Others may respond with completely different experiences.

Willy, What do you consider midsized 17"-19"? Just curious. When I was in Ontariio June 9th-16 we caught many 21"-27" trolling spinners on bottom bouncers tipped with a worm. Most of the fish we caught in 5-10 feet on windy shores. We used the slow death hook on the spinners. My 12 year olds first time in Canada and bottom bouncing and he loved it. We also searched out beaver huts and was successful around those. Scott

Same advice as one of the above. Most folks in our camp were catching fish but they were not large fish. We were told all fish were up in ten feet. We went deeper 20-25 ft and did very well on large fish. I think we caught 20 or so over 28Â”. My seven year old caught this 30.5 inch as well. First trip to Canada for him. https://uploads.tapatalk-cdn.com/201...c84b258748.jpgSent from my iPhone using Tapatalk
Beautiful fish, beautiful smile! Building memories, nice going!! Bill

Thanks for the tips. I think I'll try going deeper next time. I actually thought about that...but my grandson was catching so many fish in the 8-10' depth, it may have been a challenge to move on to something else Next year! THX
Man, your boy is setting a high bar for future trips. What a great catch! Make sure you nominate him for an Ontario Angler Award.
